hints_html:
Recall the definition of a derivative at a point \(x=a\) is

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a)=\lim_{x\to{}a}\frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}\end{aligned}\]

if the limit exists. What must be true for the limit to exist in terms of sided limits?

question: 10 (a)
sols_html:
A function \(f(x)\) is differentiable at the point \(x=2\) if the following limit exists

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 2}\frac{f(x)-f(2)}{x-2}\end{aligned}\]

Equivalently, \(f(x)\) is differentiable at the point \(x=2\) if the following limit exists

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h}\end{aligned}\]
